title-group.article-title: Pediatric Extracorporeal Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation: Development of a Porcine Model and the Influence of Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation Duration on Brain Injury
title-group.alt-title: Influence of CPR Duration on Brain Injury

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The primary objective was to develop a porcine model of prolonged (30 or 60 minutes) pediatric cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) followed by 22‐ to 24‐hour survival with extracorporeal life support, and secondarily to evaluate differences in neurologic injury.

sec.title: Methods and Results
sec.p: Ten‐kilogram, 4‐week‐old female piglets were used. First, model development established the technique (n=8). Then, a pilot study was conducted (n=15). After 80% survival was achieved in the final 5 pilot animals, a proof‐of‐concept randomized study was completed (n=11). Shams (n=6) underwent anesthesia only. Severe neurological injury was determined by a composite score of mitochondrial function, neuropathology, and cerebral metabolism: scale of 0–6 (severe: >3). Among 15 piglets in the pilot study, overall survival was 10 (67%); of the final 5, overall survival was 4 (80%). Eleven piglets were then randomized to 60 (CPR60, n=5) or 30 minutes of CPR (CPR30, n=5); 1 animal was excluded from prerandomization for intra‐abdominal hemorrhage (10/11, 91% survival). Three of 5 animals in the CPR60 group had severe neurological injury scores versus 1 of 5 in the CPR30 group (P=0.52). During ECMO, CPR60 animals had lower pH (CPR60: 7.4 [IQR 7.4–7.4] versus CPR30: 7.5 [IQR 7.4–7.5], P=0.022), higher lactate (CPR60: 6.8 [IQR 6.8–11] versus CPR30: 4.2 [IQR 4.1–4.3] mmol/L; P=0.012), and higher ICP (CPR60: 19.3 [IQR 11.7–29.3] versus CPR30: 7.9 [IQR 6.7–9.3] mm Hg; P=0.037). Both groups had greater mitochondrial injury than shams (CPR60: P<0.001; CPR30: P<0.001). CPR60 did not differ from CPR30 in mitochondrial respiration, neuropathology, or cerebral metabolism.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A pediatric porcine model of extracorporeal cardiopulmonary resuscitation after 60 and 30 minutes of CPR consistently resulted in 24‐hour survival with more severe lactic acidosis in the 60‐minute cohort.

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

For Sources of Funding and Disclosures, see page 10.

def.p: treatment group with 30 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation
treatment group with 60 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation

list-item.p: A porcine model of prolonged pediatric cardiac arrest to 30 and 60 minutes’ duration followed by 24 hours of extracorporeal life support–facilitated postcardiac arrest care was successfully developed. It is the first large‐animal model to investigate cardiopulmonary resuscitation >45 minutes in a pediatric population and to invasively measure cerebral hemodynamic, metabolic, and oxygenation parameters for 24 hours after arrest with extracorporeal life support survival.

In our proof‐of‐concept study investigating the impact of CPR duration on the severity of brain injury 24 hours after cardiac arrest, both 30 and 60 minutes of cardiac arrest resulted in severe neurological injury. However, injury severity was not entirely explained by duration of CPR, indicating that other intra‐ and postarrest factors likely play important roles in neurological recovery, with future study of these factors now possible with the establishment of this translational model.

body.p: Pediatric cardiac arrest in the United States constitutes a significant public health burden, with an estimated 15 000 in‐hospital cardiac arrests and 23 0001 out‐of‐hospital cardiac arrests2 annually. The earliest possible reestablishment of sustained blood flow is critical to survival and neurological outcome, and extracorporeal cardiopulmonary resuscitation (ECPR) techniques are now widely used for refractory cardiac arrests. In children with cardiac diagnoses in well‐equipped centers, ECPR is associated with improved survival and neurological recovery after prolonged in‐hospital cardiac arrest3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and is now endorsed in resuscitation guidelines8 for these patients. High‐quality research is necessary to extend ECPR to other populations and settings and to optimize its functionality and outcomes.

As ECPR usage increases and survival from in‐hospital cardiac arrests of even longer duration becomes possible, advanced understanding of the relationship between cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) duration and neurological outcome will become even more important. Neurologically intact survival is possible after prolonged arrests even >120 minutes and can be as high as 16% in certain pediatric patient populations after >35 minutes CPR,9, 10 but it remains unknown why this is possible for some patients and not others. Gaps in present knowledge, including systemic and cerebral physiologic factors contributing to poor neurologic outcome, can be partly addressed though the development of high‐fidelity translational models. However, large animal models exploring the physiology of CPR >30 minutes’ duration are decades old,11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17 and ECPR translational models with postarrest extracorporeal support beyond 6 hours or in a pediatric population have not been published. Therefore, the primary objective of this study was to develop a swine model of prolonged pediatric cardiac arrest and CPR, followed by venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA‐ECMO) cannulation and maintenance for 24 hours after arrest. The secondary objective was to use this model in a proof‐of‐concept study assessing the impact of cardiac arrest and CPR duration (30 minutes versus 60 minutes) on the severity of brain injury.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee approved the experimental protocol, which is in concordance with the National Institutes of Health Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. Additional detail is provided in Data S1. All data and supporting materials are available within the article and its online supplementary files.

sec.title: Animal Preparation and Measurements
sec.p: Eight healthy, 1‐month‐old (≈10 kg), female Yorkshire piglets were used in model development to establish technique without intention of survival. A subsequent 15 animals were included in a pilot study conducted with intention of 22‐ to 24‐hour survival with extracorporeal support. This period was chosen in this proof‐of‐concept study since it was anticipated to be the most difficult to achieve, with the highest severity of inflammation and need for circulatory support after out‐of‐hospital cardiac arrest.18 The primary aim of this study was model establishment. Criteria for completion of the pilot study was 80% survival of the final 5 pilot animals, chosen to demonstrate sufficient technical progress and the ability to conduct successful, standardized experiments. Following the pilot study, 11 animals were enrolled in a randomized, proof‐of‐concept study. See Data S1 for details on animal preparation, anesthesia, and instrumentation. Comprehensive descriptions of animal preparation are available in our previous publications.19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24 The clinical relevance of our porcine asphyxia‐associated in‐hospital cardiac arrest model is described in previous publications.25, 26

sec.title: Study Protocol
sec.p:
Figure 1 summarizes study design.
Asphyxia and induction of cardiac arrest: 12 minutes before the start of asphyxia, anesthetic infusions of ketamine 5 mg/kg per hour and dexmedetomidine 5 μg/kg per hour were started, and 60 μg of intramuscular buprenorphine was administered. Infusions were titrated to no pinch or blink response to confirm anesthetic plane. After baseline measurements, animals underwent 7 minutes of asphyxia via endotracheal tube clamping, followed by induction of ventricular fibrillation with 2 unipolar pacing needles placed via transcutaneous insertion into the right ventricle.
Resuscitation: animals were randomized to 1 of the following treatment groups: 60 minutes of cardiac arrest and CPR (CPR60), or 30 minutes of cardiac arrest and CPR (CPR30). After confirmation of ventricular fibrillation, all animals immediately received hemodynamic‐directed CPR, a resuscitation method described in previous publications.19, 20, 21 Briefly, chest compression depth/force was titrated to meet a systolic blood pressure goal of 90 mm Hg, and vasopressor administration with both epinephrine (0.02 mg/kg) and vasopressin (0.4 U/kg) was titrated to coronary perfusion pressure ≥20 mm Hg. Animals were ventilated in volume control with 10 mL/kg of tidal volume, a rate of 10 breaths per minute, end expiratory pressure of 5 mm Hg, and 100% fraction of inspired oxygen.
VA‐ECMO cannulation and initiation: 5 minutes before the end of CPR, 30‐second interruptions in CPR were introduced for surgical cannulation, each followed by 60 seconds of chest compressions to minimize and standardize interruptions in blood flow. Wires placed before asphyxia were replaced with an arterial cannula (10Fr Biomedicus cannulas, Medtronic) in the right carotid artery and a cannula in the right external jugular vein (14Fr Biomedicus cannulas, Medtronic). Cannulas were not placed before resuscitation to avoid vascular obstruction and injury during chest compressions and to reproduce real‐time ECPR cannulation. Immediately before the establishment of VA‐ECMO flow, animals were defibrillated, and a heparin bolus of 500 IU and a 200‐mL normal saline bolus were administered. Intravenous anesthetic infusions were resumed.
VA‐ECMO management: immediately upon initiation of ECMO, defibrillation (50 J) was attempted until an organized rhythm was reestablished. Flow was increased to target flow rates of 60 to 80 mL/kg per minute to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) goal of 55 to 80 mm Hg. A clinically relevant VA‐ECMO circuit, described in Data S1, was used. Heparin dosing was titrated to maintain activated clotting time of 180 to 220. Crystalloid boluses, vasoactive infusions, calcium, bicarbonate, dextrose, and sedative infusions were titrated to maintain a priori hemodynamic and metabolic targets and a surgical plane of anesthesia by an intensive care physician (Table S1).

caption.title: Experimental methods.
caption.p: CPR indicates cardiopulmonary resuscitation; ECMO, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation; EEG, electroencephalogram; HD‐CPR, hemodynamic‐directed CPR; MAP, mean arterial pressure; and SBP, systolic blood pressure.

sec.title: Study Measures
sec.p: Data from systemic, pulmonary, and cerebral hemodynamics; respiratory mechanics; CPR mechanics; cerebral oxygenation; intracranial pressure; electroencephalogram; and VA‐ECMO blood flow and gas exchange were collected continuously throughout the experiment. Arterial and mixed venous blood gases and cerebral microdialysis samples were collected at 20 minutes and 40 minutes during CPR and hourly in the 24‐hour postarrest period. Noninvasive quantification of cerebral tissue oxygen saturation (%), total hemoglobin concentration (%), cerebral metabolic rate (mL O2/100 mg brain/min), and oxygen extraction fraction (%) were achieved by frequency‐domain diffuse optical spectroscopy. See Data S1 for more detailed data acquisition techniques.

sec.title: Euthanasia, Mitochondrial Analyses, Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: Animals remained on protocolized VA‐ECMO support for 22 to 24 hours. Subsequently, euthanasia was humanely performed, and fresh cerebral tissue underwent immediate ex vivo mitochondrial respirometry analyses. Additional samples were formalin‐fixed and frozen for neuropathology. See Data S1 for detailed protocols. Briefly, high‐resolution mitochondrial respirometry was performed on cortical and hippocampal specimens using a substrate, uncoupler, inhibitor titration protocol as previously described,27, 28 and reactive oxygen species were quantified using superoxide dismutase. Samples underwent immunohistochemical analyses to identify astrocyte activation with glial fibrillary acidic protein, microglial activation with ionized calcium‐binding adaptor molecule 1, and apoptosis with cleaved caspase‐8. Slides were reviewed and scored on a binary scale by an experienced neuropathologist blinded to group assignment.

A neurological injury severity score was created to combine multiple metrics of neurological injury (Table). For each metric (mitochondrial respiration, neuropathology, and cerebral metabolism), the total population was divided on a binary scale, and injury points were awarded for each component. The score used respiratory control ratio for coupled oxidative phosphorylation (maximal, coupled oxidative phosphorylation/state 4o respiration without ATP production), which evaluates phosphorylation coupling efficiency, as a global marker of mitochondrial function. The score incorporated glial fibrillary acidic protein and ionized calcium‐binding adaptor molecule 1 as neuropathologic indicators of inflammation and tissue injury, the final glycerol measurement as an indicator of overall cellular membrane damage, and the average lactate/pyruvate ratio over the final 6 hours of the experiment as a measure of anaerobic and cerebral metabolism.

fn.p: Markers of overall mitochondrial function represented by cortex respiratory control ratio (RCR) and maximal oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOSCI+CII), markers of neuropathologic injury represented by immunohistochemical stains GFAP and IBA‐1, as well as markers of altered cerebral metabolism obtained via cerebral microdialysis sampling of lactate, pyruvate and glycerol are included for each animal to indicate overall injury severity. Animal number 3 in the 30‐minute treatment group suffered an intracranial hemorrhage 6 hours into the ECMO period. GFAP indicates glial fibrillary acidic protein; IBA‐1, ionized calcium‐binding adaptor molecule 1; OXPHOS, oxidative phosphorylation; and RCR, respiratory control ratio.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: For the secondary objective comparing CPR duration groups, the primary outcome was the overall neurological injury severity score. The scale ranged from 0 to 6 points, with 6 as the highest injury level. A composite score of ≤3 was considered a good outcome. We also evaluated an alternative threshold of ≤2. Secondary outcomes included characterization of cerebral and systemic hemodynamics following injury over 24 hours of postarrest care on VA‐ECMO.

Data were presented as medians with interquartile ranges at predefined time points (baseline period, overall period of CPR administration, every 10 minutes during CPR up to 30 minutes, 50 minutes into CPR, and last value during CPR), as well as at 6 prespecified time points during the postarrest VA‐ECMO period (before 1 hour and 1, 6, 12, 18, and 21 hours) and compared between groups using Wilcoxon rank‐sum tests.

A segmented mixed‐effects regression model was employed to compare longitudinal physiologic data between groups. Fixed effects in the model included time (5 segments), CPR intervention groups (CPR60 versus CPR30) and the interaction of time and intervention groups. The 5 CPR segments corresponded to baseline period, baseline through CPR start (ie, asphyxia), the first 5 minutes of CPR, 5 to 30 minutes of CPR, and 30 to 55 minutes CPR. The 5 segments during the 24 hours after arrest on VA‐ECMO used cut points at 1, 6, 12, and 18 hours.

Mitochondrial respiration measurements were compared between groups using the Wilcoxon rank‐sum test. Neurological injury severity scores and histopathology findings were compared with Fisher's exact test. Statistical analyses were performed with STATA version 15.1 (Statacorp LP, College Station, TX), Prism version 7 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA), and DESeq2 package for R version X (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria).

sec.title: Model Development
sec.p: Among 15 animals in a pilot study, overall survival through the ECMO period was 10 of 15 (67%). Three of the first 5 animals (60%), 4 of the second 5 (80%), and 4 of the final 5 (80%) survived. Reasons for attrition included prolonged cannulation time (>30 minutes; n=1), intra‐abdominal hemorrhage (n=2), bilateral pneumothoraces (n=1), and cessation of VA‐ECMO circuit flow at 19 hours because of progressive anasarca. Challenges encountered in the pilot study included tension pneumothoraces caused by rib fractures, addressed with empiric placement of bilateral chest tubes before CPR; frequent bleeding on ECMO, addressed with heparin dose titration; and inadequate ECMO flow rates, addressed with the use of a 14Fr venous cannula.

Of the 11 animals that were then enrolled in the proof‐of‐concept study, 1 was excluded because of intra‐abdominal hemorrhage leading to nonsurvival. The remaining 10 animals were successfully randomized to receive either 60 minutes of CPR (CPR60 group; n=5) or 30 minutes of CPR (CPR30 group; n=5) (Figure 2). One animal in CPR30 developed an intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) 6 hours into the postarrest period on VA‐ECMO. Data from this animal after the ICH at 6 hours were excluded from cerebral hemodynamic and oxygenation analyses, but this animal was included in the primary outcome.

caption.title: Model development and study population.
caption.p: CPR indicates cardiopulmonary resuscitation; ECMO, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation; and HD‐CPR, hemodynamic‐directed CPR.

sec.title: Baseline and Cardiac Arrest
sec.p: CPR60 and CPR30 treatment groups did not differ at baseline through CPR for any hemodynamic, cerebral, or metabolic parameter (Figure 3, Tables S3 and S4). CPR60 animals received more doses of vasopressor (P=0.011 for epinephrine and P=0.011 for vasopressin) and had longer total pause time over the course of the arrest (P=0.037) but not during the first 30 minutes of CPR (Table S5). Groups did not differ in any physiologic measure, pause time, or vasopressor dosage through the first 25 minutes of CPR (Tables S4 and S5).

caption.title: Intra‐arrest physiology over 30 (n=5) or 60 (n=5) minutes of CPR.
caption.p: Data shown are from a mixed effects model comparing predicted values for each group, 30‐minutes CPR and 60‐minutes CPR. Values are predicted difference (standard error) between 60‐minutes CPR versus 30‐minutes CPR. Time was coded differently for variables measured at different frequencies. CBF indicates cerebral blood flow; CoPP, coronary artery perfusion pressure; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; EtCO2, end tidal carbon dioxide; ICP, intracranial pressure; L/P, lactate/pyruvate ratio; MD, cerebral microdialysis; PbtO2, brain tissue oxygenation; and SBP, systolic blood pressure,

sec.title: VA‐ECMO Period
sec.p: During VA‐ECMO, groups significantly differed in average pH (CPR60: 7.4 [IQR 7.4–7.4] versus CPR30: 7.5 [IQR 7.4–7.5]; P=0.022), arterial lactate (CPR60: 6.8 [IQR 6.8–11] versus CPR30: 4.2 [IQR 4.1–4.3] mmol/L; P=0.012), ICP (CPR60: 19.3 [IQR 11.7–29.3] versus CPR30: 7.9 [IQR 6.7–9.3] mm Hg, P=0.037), and in the total amount of nicardipine required (CPR60 0.2 [IQR 0.2–0.3] versus, CPR30: 0.6 [IQR 0.5–1.1] μg/kg; P=0.022) (Table S6). Three animals in CPR60 and 2 animals in CPR30 received epinephrine. Among those receiving epinephrine in CPR60, the total dose of epinephrine administered ranged from 198 to 1068 μg/kg compared with 6 to 12 μg/kg in CPR30 (P=0.27) (Table S6) over 24 hours. Circuit flow rates were 62.8 (IQR 58.7–66.2) mL/kg per minute in CPR60 versus 80.3 (IQR 70.1–89.0) mL/kg per min in CPR30 (P=0.09).

Cerebral blood flow (CBF) (CPR60: 35.3 [IQR 7.3–37.1] versus CPR30: 51.1 [IQR 42.4–76.9] % baseline; P=0.18), brain tissue oxygenation (CPR60: 21.1 [IQR 16.6–26.9] mm Hg versus CPR30: 14.7 [IQR 13.3–16.3]; P=0.27), and oxygen extraction fraction (CPR60: 18.5% [IQR 0.7%–39.1%] versus CPR30: 0.6 [IQR 0.6–0.7]; P=0.31) did not differ significantly between groups (Table S6). Using a mixed effects model, differences between groups were significant for lactate/pyruvate ratio at 18 (P<0.05) and 21 hours (P<0.001) (Table S7), with greater anaerobic metabolism in CPR60.

sec.title: Composite Injury Score
sec.p: For the primary outcome in which ≤3 points defined a good outcome, 3 of 5 animals in CPR60 had good outcomes compared with 4 of 5 animals in CPR30 (P=0.52). The 1 animal in CPR30 with a score >3 suffered an ICH during VA‐ECMO. When the alternate threshold of ≤2 points was applied, good outcomes were observed in 2 of 5 animals in CPR60 versus 3 of 5 animals in CPR30 (P=1) (Table).

sec.title: Neuropathologic Injury
sec.p: In both CPR60 and CPR30 groups, 2 of 5 animals had high numbers of reactive astrocytes with prominent cytoplasm in the white matter and cortex detected by elevated glial fibrillary acidic protein (P=1.00). In both CPR60 and in CPR30 groups, 3 of 5 animals had high levels of microglial/macrophage activation as demonstrated by elevated ionized calcium‐binding adaptor molecule 1 (P=1.00). In CPR60, 2 of 5 animals had high levels of cell death as evidenced by apoptotic marker cleaved caspase‐8 compared with 3 of 5 animals in CPR30 (Table S8; [P=0.53]).

sec.title: Cerebral Mitochondrial Respiration
sec.p: Cerebral mitochondrial respiration did not differ between CPR duration groups, but compared with sham animals that received 24 hours of anesthesia only, both groups exhibited significantly worse overall dysfunction as represented by respiratory control ratio in the cortex (sham versus CPR60, P<0.001; sham versus CPR30, P<0.001) and in the hippocampus (sham versus CPR60, P<0.01; sham versus CPR30, P<0.01) (Figure 4). This dysfunction was mediated by significantly worse maximal, coupled oxidative phosphorylation via complex I, complex I and II, and complex IV function. No significant difference was noted between CPR treatment groups and sham animals in state 4o respiration without ATP production (LEAK), representing mitochondrial membrane integrity (Table S9).

caption.title: Mitochondrial respiration at 24 hours following cardiac arrest.
caption.p: Wilcoxon rank‐sum test was used for nonnormally distributed data. Values are median (interquartile range). CI indicates complex I; CII, complex II; CPR30, treatment group that received CPR for 30 minutes; CPR60, treatment group that received CPR for 60 minutes; ICH, intracerebral hemorrhage; LEAK, state 4o respiration without ATP production; OXPHOS, oxidative phosphorylating capacity; and RCR, respiratory control ratio.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we successfully developed and piloted a porcine model of prolonged pediatric cardiac arrest of 30 and 60 minutes’ duration followed by 24 hours of extracorporeal life support (ECLS)‐facilitated postcardiac arrest care. To our knowledge, this is the first large‐animal model in decades to investigate CPR >45 minutes,3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 29, 30 as well as to invasively measure postarrest cerebral hemodynamic, metabolic, and oxygenation parameters for 24 hours after arrest. In our proof‐of‐concept study investigating the impact of CPR duration on the severity of brain injury 24 hours after cardiac arrest, all animals suffered neurological injury (Table), but the severity of injury was not demonstrably different between groups nor entirely explained by CPR duration.

This model is clinically significant in its standardized, high‐fidelity reproduction of prolonged cardiac arrest followed by the crucial first 24 hours of cerebral and systemic ischemia–reperfusion injury. To replicate increasingly severe clinical injuries, longer durations of CPR are needed in translational models, as well as longer postarrest monitoring to understand the evolution of cerebral injury. The first 24 hours following ECLS implementation has been compared with an ongoing septic shock state with cytokine storm, nitric oxide release, and resulting vasoplegia that not only affect systemic and cerebral hemodynamics and recovery but impair ECMO pump flow.31, 32 The smaller 10‐kg piglets used in this study created additional challenges in establishing sufficient ECMO pump flow but added value in dedicated study to pediatric anatomy and physiology, with 1‐month‐old piglets having similar neuroanatomy and neurodevelopment to pediatric patients.25, 26 Unlike many swine ECPR models that simulate cardiac arrest with low ECLS flow rates,30, 33, 34 this model provided 30 or 60 minutes of chest compressions, leading to various injuries with clinically relevant hemodynamic consequences, such as liver lacerations with intra‐abdominal hemorrhage and rib fractures leading to hemothoraces and pneumothoraces, likely the result of CPR‐related rib fractures or worsened compliance and high peak inspiratory pressures during prolonged CPR.

To achieve a reproducible injury and resuscitation with 91% survival in the final study (10/11), 34 total animal experiments were conducted given the complexity of the model design. The final population included in the proof‐of‐concept study is inherently limited by sample size, but the established feasibility will now allow for future investigation into cerebral blood flow, metabolism, and oxygenation, as well as the effects of intra‐ and postarrest clinical management on cerebral autoregulation, microcirculatory injury, and neurological outcome.

A secondary objective of this study was to assess the impact of CPR duration on the severity of brain injury measured 24 hours after cardiac arrest. All animals in both groups suffered severe neurological dysfunction and injury as measured by cerebral mitochondrial respirometry (Figure 4), neuropathologic analyses (Table S8), and cerebral microdialysis (Table S6), consistent with findings from other studies.35, 36 Interestingly, the proton gradient and inner membrane were not significantly different from sham animals as evidenced by state 4o respiration without ATP production, which may suggest functional rather than structural mitochondrial injury. Notably, 12 hours into VA‐ECMO, lactate/pyruvate ratios and glycerol levels rise in CPR60 animals (Figure S1) but not significantly. This finding, also seen in another swine study of ECPR duration,35 could indicate greater ischemic burden or progression of secondary injury processes37 despite restoration of circulation. This would support development and use of postcardiac arrest neuromonitoring modalities that measure CBF, autoregulation, and oxygenation in real time, informing clinical management and prognostication.38

Injury patterns and severity were variable within CPR duration groups and did not definitively differ between groups. Three of 5 CPR60 animals had high levels of injury compared with 2 animals in CPR30: 1 with ICH and another with an injury score of 3 of 6 that could be interpreted as lesser or greater depending on the threshold. Interestingly, 2 of 5 animals in CPR60 had lesser overall neurological injury scores than some animals in CPR30. This corresponds with the well‐established but inconsistent observations of favorable neurological outcomes in patients after even extreme durations of CPR.9 Thus, 60 minutes of cardiac arrest is not a universally devastating injury, and even in this well‐controlled laboratory setting other neuroprotective or neurotoxic factors apparently mitigate or exaggerate the effects of prolonged hypoperfusion. The postarrest period, with the potential for both secondary injury and therapeutic intervention, likely contains many of these factors.

Therefore, secondary objectives included characterizing cerebral and systemic hemodynamics over 24 hours of VA‐ECMO therapy. As evidenced by significantly lower pH and higher arterial lactate, the CPR60 group likely experienced a more severe shock state (Table S6). Although not significant (P=0.09), circuit flow rates were more difficult to achieve in this group likely because of worse vasomotor dysfunction, endothelial damage, and myocardial depression. The postcardiac arrest shock state is characterized by a proinflammatory response, potential increases in left ventricular afterload generated by VA‐ECMO, and lactic acidemia, which is both cardiotoxic and associated with worse neurological outcomes.39, 40, 41 Despite worsened lactic acidemia, CPR60 animals maintained similar MAPs, central venous oxygen saturations and brain tissue oxygenation levels throughout VA‐ECMO (Figure S1). This pathophysiology represents an important target for therapeutic interventions in future studies.

Understanding additional neuroprotective or neurotoxic factors should become the focus of the next phase of research driven by this proof‐of‐concept study. We hypothesize that maintenance of cerebrovascular autoregulation is likely one neuroprotective factor that deserves further investigation. Clinical ECMO management uses age‐based MAP goals and weight‐based ECMO flow rates,39 and MAP achieved is often discrepant from the optimal MAP required to maintain autoregulation.42 As demonstrated in a recent ECPR swine model, a higher MAP target is beneficial to autoregulation during cardiac arrest yet detrimental after arrest.33 The inability to maintain or control CBF after arrest is associated with worse neurological outcomes,43 and while the heterogeneity in this study population, with average CBFs from 12% to 296% of baseline values during CPR and 7% to 139% during VA‐ECMO, limits conclusions that can be drawn, an inability to manage CBF attributable to deranged autoregulation likely contributed to injury and deserves further study.

Our findings may have clinical implications for ECPR cannulation timing and postarrest ECMO management. Time without sufficient circulation is an important prognostic factor,44 but gone is the era in which CPR was considered futile beyond 20 minutes or after 2 doses of epinephrine.45, 46, 47 Data from this study further substantiate clinical data showing that 60 minutes of CPR is not a universally devastating cerebral injury and support current efforts to accelerate ECPR program implementation.9, 10 ECPR programs and protocols must consider an optimal time for cannulation while not necessarily excluding patients with longer durations of CPR. If the ideal time to ECPR is the shortest possible while avoiding harm to those who would have survived with standard CPR alone, proposed times to cannulation range from 2048, 49 and 30 minutes50 to 60 minutes.10 Given this lack of consensus, ECPR programs lack standardization and vary widely.48 A duration of CPR cutoff to predict futility may not exist, as many pre‐, intra‐, and postarrest factors influence outcome. Better elucidation of these issues may lead to future intra‐ and postarrest interventions.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: A principal limitation of this proof‐of‐concept study is that its small sample size prohibited the detection of statistically significant differences between the CPR60 and CPR30 groups. The primary objective was demonstrating the achievability of developing a novel porcine model, so future investigation in a larger study is required to investigate the relationship between postarrest cerebral physiology and severity of brain injury.

Translation of the findings of this proof‐of‐concept study to the bedside is limited by the duration of survival and use of surrogate outcomes rather than the functional neurologic status of the subjects. Neurofunctional outcomes and brain magnetic resonance imaging findings at time points past the peak of postarrest cerebral edema and secondary injury51 will enhance clinical relevance of future work in this model. In the present study, these outcomes were precluded by injury severity and cranial instrumentation, but they are feasible52 and should be emphasized in future research. While cardiac arrest preceded by hypoxemia may result in a different neurologic injury than if preceded by arrhythmia or cardiac failure, a well‐established asphyxia‐associated model was chosen because of the high incidence of respiratory insufficiency in both the cardiac and noncardiac populations.4 Future translational CPR work should model primary cardiac disease since these patients account for a substantial number of children requiring in‐hospital CPR.

Another limitation toward clinical relevance is that wires were placed in the internal jugular vein and internal carotid artery before the initiation of CPR; this allowed for consistent cannulation times within groups (Table S5), which were desired to decrease confounding and minimize the variability of the pericannulation “no‐flow.” Our study protocol also used standardized, brief interruptions in chest compressions during cannulation (30‐second pause followed by 60 seconds of chest compressions) to minimize confounding variability. Although it is possible to keep chest compression fraction >80% during the past 5 minutes of CPR before ECPR cannulation,53 there is more variation clinically in terms of chest compression mechanics and interruptions,54 and this should be a future objective of clinical research. There was a lack of left ventricular unloading and the likely development of pulmonary congestion and edema, which could have been ameliorated clinically. We did not specifically assess myocardial recovery through echocardiography or analysis of pulsatility while on VA‐ECMO, which deserve attention in future work. Also, other markers of organ injury, such as renal or liver function testing, were not available and should be incorporated in future research. One animal did suffer ICH, eliminating it from the interpretation of postarrest cerebral hemodynamics and further decreasing the power of the study, but this 10% (1/10) incidence is similar to the clinical incidence of ICH on VA‐ECMO.55, 56

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A porcine model of prolonged pediatric cardiac arrest to 30 and 60 minutes’ duration followed by 24 hours of ECLS‐facilitated postcardiac arrest care was successfully developed. It is the first large‐animal model to investigate CPR >45 minutes, with 24 hours of ECLS survival, and in a pediatric population. Additionally, both 30 and 60 minutes of cardiac arrest resulted in severe neurological injury, but injury severity was not entirely explained by duration of CPR, indicating that other intra‐ and postarrest factors likely play important roles in neurological recovery, with future study of these factors now possible with the establishment of this translational model.

sec.title: Sources of Funding
sec.p: This work was funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (R21HD089132; PI: RAB) and National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (R01HL141386; PI: TJK) and was also supported by the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care Medicine. Dr Morgan's effort was supported by an NIH National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Career Development Award (K23HL148541). Dr Hefti's effort was supported by an NIH National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Career Development Award (K23NS1092840). In addition, this work was funded by the Department of Anesthesia and Critical Care Medicine at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Research Institute Resuscitation Science Center, and the Raymond Foundation. Unrelated disclosures include the following: Drs Nadkarni and Berg receive grant funding from the NIH. Dr Kilbaugh receives grant funding from the NIH, the Department of Defense, and nonprofit foundations and has previously received investigator‐initiated grant support from Mallinckrodt Corporation for a different laboratory study.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Anna Roberts currently is employed by Abiomed, but her employment began after her work on this article was complete. The remaining authors have no disclosures to report.

caption.p: Click here for additional data file.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee and Laboratory Animal Facilities staff, and Bingqing Zhang, Heather Griffis, and Steve Ampah with the Healthcare Analytics Unit (HAU) Core for their statistical analysis.

The authors confirm contribution to the paper as follows: study conception and design: TJK, CM, RAB, RMS, RWM, VM, JCS. Data collection: JCS, LV, CM, WPL, ALR, ND, TH, KG, JS, YL, RM, RWM, TJK. Analysis and interpretation of the results: JCS, LV, CM, MH, WPL, ALR, ND, TH, KG, JS, VM, RMS, RAB, SP, TWM, TJK. Draft manuscript and preparation: JCS, RWM, TJK, RAB, VM, RS. All authors reviewed the results and approved the final version of the manuscript.
